entries.title: Munetaka Murakami, fashionably late, impresses in Cactus League debut
entries.summary: <p>MESA, Ariz. ‚Äî Munetaka Murakami is rarely seen in the White Sox clubhouse for an extended period of time.</p><p>From one workout to another, he‚Äôs always on the move ‚Äî except for on his ride to Sloan Park for Friday‚Äôs Cactus League opener against the Cubs.</p><p>Murakami and numerous other Sox were stuck in traffic due to a crash on the interstate, nearly scratching the Japanese slugger from his first Spring Training start. He made it just in time, minutes before first pitch, and batted cleanup and started at first base.</p><p>‚ÄúOh my god!‚Äù Murakami said in English after the game when asked about running late, punching his fist animating a crash.</p><p>‚ÄúI‚Äôm really happy how it went without any injuries,‚Äù Murakami said through translator Kenzo Yagi. He was still in the car at 12:50 p.m. for the 1:05 p.m. start, he noted.</p><p>‚ÄúI had butterflies inside me the first few minutes of it. But after I started fielding and I got an at-bat, I felt a bit more comfortable and felt myself,‚Äù Murakami said.</p><p>All snafus aside, Murakami came inches away from a grand slam when his countryman Seiya Suzuki lost a fly ball in the sun and let it drop on the warning track. It turned into a two-run double.</p><p>‚ÄúIt was a great at-bat. I was able to get good angles on the bat and velocity. I‚Äôm really happy how it went and how it went over my friend as well,‚Äù Murakami said.</p><p>Sox manager Will Venable commended Murakami‚Äôs ability to ‚Äúcollect himself‚Äù quickly and still be able to put together a 2-for-4 day with a two-run double, single and a strikeout in the Sox‚Äô 8-1 win.</p><p>Asked about his first impression of Murakami so far in spring camp, new Sox hitting coach Derek Shomon used one word: ‚Äúworker.‚Äù</p><p>‚Äú[He] does not shy away from the work,‚Äù Shomon said. ‚ÄúBeen very clear about wanting the information. [He] wants to utilize the resources that we have. I think more times than not it might be trying to pull him out of the cage and remind him to breathe, than to having to push him in the cage to actually get work done. The guy works really hard. It‚Äôs been fun to see.‚Äù</p><p>At first base, Murakami knocked down a hard-hit groundball (112 mph exit velocity), corralled it and tossed to pitcher Jonathan Cannon for his first assist.</p><p>‚ÄúI‚Äôm trying really hard to get adjusted to the field work,‚Äù Murakami, 26, said, adding that third baseman Miguel Vargas has provided some defensive tips so far in camp.</p><p>Sox manager Will Venable said he‚Äôll give the corner infielder some playing time at third base, especially ahead of the World Baseball Classic next month since he‚Äôll likely see a bulk of time there for Team Japan.</p><p>Murakami said he plans to play in five Cactus League games before departing for the WBC.</p><p>The Sox signed the 6-foot-2, 213 lb. right-hander to a two-year $12 million deal in December, making him one of the most distinguished international free-agent signings in franchise history.</p><p>In Japan, Murakami won back-to-back MVPs in 2021 and 2022. The latter year, at age 22, he set the Nippon Professional Baseball league record as the youngest triple crown winner and set the single-season home run record with 56 homers.</p><p>Murakami has been knocked for his high whiff rate, which he is well aware of.</p><p>‚ÄúThis guy‚Äôs smart, he really is. The aptitude is there. He has an understanding of likely what is going to be exposed and he‚Äôs doing a really good job attacking it on a daily basis and being really intentional with his work,‚Äù Shomon said.</p>
entries.author: Kade Heather

entries.title: Sophia McMillan's relentless ball pressure helps Fremd capture a Class 4A regional championship
entries.summary:
Win or lose, Fremd ‚Äî which went downstate the last two seasons and reached the Class 4A championship game a year ago ‚Äî knew its game Friday would be its last on its home floor this season.

The Vikings didn‚Äôt get off to the start they wanted to, fouling too much and allowing too many easy baskets. But they increased the pressure in the second quarter, and senior guard Sophia McMillan was the catalyst.

‚Äò‚ÄòShe‚Äôs one of our magic puzzle pieces,‚Äô‚Äô Fremd coach James Weaver said. ‚Äò‚ÄòWe can put her on a big [player], put her on a small.‚Äô‚Äô

McMillan raised the Vikings‚Äô defensive intensity, suffocating Barrington‚Äôs ballhandlers and cutting off their every dribble. Her stifling defense forced the Broncos into multiple turnovers.

Fremd took control of the game after allowing only three points in the second quarter and coasted to a 60-30 victory in the title game of a Class 4A regional to advance to the sectional semifinals.

‚Äò‚ÄòWe started pressing them as a team and being connected on the floor, [which] really helped us with getting steals,‚Äô‚Äô said McMillan, who scored seven of her 11 points in the second quarter.

Senior Greta Thompson was also a key to the Vikings‚Äô lockdown quarter. She used great anticipation to come up with back-to-back steals that led to Fremd baskets.

‚Äò‚ÄòThat‚Äôs the one thing that we‚Äôve been saying all playoffs: We have to play together,‚Äô‚Äô said Thompson, who scored 13 points.

Junior guard Grace Todd joined McMillan with 11 points, and senior forward Isabella Del Mar added four points and six rebounds.

Creating havoc defensively enabled the Vikings‚Äô transition offense to thrive. Barrington wasn‚Äôt ready for Fremd‚Äôs run-and-jump defensive tactics.

The Vikings don‚Äôt have one player who dominates the ball offensively. Instead, they run a motion offense predicated on driving and kicking the ball out to open teammates to create advantages.

Fremd‚Äôs doesn‚Äôt have the tallest players, either, but the Vikings are strong at covering for each other defensively and competing for rebounds. If a player gambles for a steal, teammates are ready to help until that player is back in position.

Fremd has nine seniors on its roster. They wanted to go out in style on their home floor.

‚Äò‚Äò[The game] was emotional because I care so much about this program,‚Äô‚Äô Thompson said. ‚Äò‚ÄòGoing into this game, I felt like, ‚ÄòOK, we‚Äôve gotta just leave everything we have because it‚Äôs our last time playing here.‚Äô‚Äâ‚Äô‚Äô

McMillan will be done playing basketball after this playoff run, so she‚Äôs soaking in every moment. She has committed to Illinois to play soccer.

‚Äò‚ÄòIt‚Äôs an amazing feeling as a senior,‚Äô‚Äô McMillan said. ‚Äò‚ÄòEach game is just so surreal. Going downstate is definitely our goal.‚Äô‚Äô

Kenwood, the defending Class 4A champion, was upset by Hinsdale Central in its regional championship game. If the Vikings can remain as connected defensively and play with as much energy as they did against the Broncos, then they‚Äôll give themselves a chance against most teams.

Fremd will play Hersey in the sectional semifinals Tuesday at Schaumburg.

‚Äò‚ÄòSurvive and advance, right?‚Äô‚Äô Weaver said.
entries.author: Kyle Williams

entries.title: 17-year-old charged in carjacking and shooting deaths in Lake View and Bronzeville
entries.summary: <p>Police announced charges Friday for a 17-year-old boy who authorities say was involved in the slayings of two men that happened an hour apart during linked carjackings earlier this month in <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/lakeview" target="_blank" >Lake View</a> and Bronzeville.</p><p>The boy was arrested Thursday, according to police. He faces charges of first-degree murder, vehicular hijacking, attempted vehicular hijacking and aggravated discharge of a firearm. </p><p>Another person of interest remains in custody. </p><p><a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/crime/2026/02/12/murderslinked" target="_blank" >Darwin Tirado, 22, and Damon Kellum, 45, were killed about an hour apart in the Feb. 11 attacks</a>, according to the Cook County medical examiner‚Äôs office and police.</p><div class="RelatedList Enhancement" data-module data-align-center> <div class="RelatedList-title">Related</div> <ul class="RelatedList-items"> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/crime/2021/12/31/22848890/chicago-carjackings-inside-mind-chicago-carjacker" >Inside the mind of a Chicago carjacker</a> </li> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/the-watchdogs/2025/06/06/kid-carjackers-srt-boys-carjackings-burglaries-north-lawndale-juvenile-crime" >Chicago‚Äôs kid carjackers: Inside the SRT Boys‚Äô yearslong crime spree</a> </li> </ul> </div> <p>Tirado was in the 700 block of West Waveland Avenue shortly before 4 a.m., sitting in a parked car, having a conversation with a 38-year-old man after the two had left a nearby tavern when two people attacked them, killing Tirado and fleeing in his car, according to police reports. The 38-year-old was not injured. </p><p>About an hour later and 12 miles away in <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/bronzeville" >Bronzeville,</a> Kellum was gunned down in the 3700 block of South Lake Park Avenue, and Tirado‚Äôs car was found nearby, according to police, who said the two assailants tried at least twice more to carjack vehicles after the killings on the same day, police said. </p>
entries.author: Sun-Times Wire

entries.title: Man, 20, shot, wounded in South Shore
entries.summary: <p>A 20-year-old is in critical condition after he was shot in South Shore on Friday evening. </p><p>The man was on the sidewalk in the 7100 block of South Yates Boulevard at about 5:15 p.m. when he was shot by an unknown offender, police said. The victim sustained multiple gunshot wounds and was taken to University of Chicago Medical Center in critical condition. </p><p>No one is in custody, and Area One Detectives are investigating.</p>
entries.author: Sun-Times Wire

entries.title: Unions demand more from Pritzker for education
entries.summary: <p>As expected, we did not see a whole lot of spending increases in Gov. JB Pritzker‚Äôs <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/springfield/2026/02/18/jb-pritzker-budget-proposal-state-of-state-social-media-tax" >state budget proposal</a> last week.</p><p>Last year, Pritzker said his budget limited discretionary spending to less than a 1 percent increase. The plan unveiled last week limits discretionary spending to less than a half a point increase.</p><p>An education funding lobby day was held the day before the budget address in Springfield. The teachers unions decried the state for not living up to its evidence-based funding law, which was supposed to bring all schools up to 90% ‚Äúadequate‚Äù funding levels by next year.</p><p>Instead, the annual evidence-based funding ramp is way behind, and the unions say the state won‚Äôt reach its target until 2034. So, they claim, the state ‚Äúowes‚Äù K-12 schools $5 billion and ‚Äúowes‚Äù higher education another $1 billion. And, as they‚Äôve been demanding for a while, they want it all now.</p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-c00000" name="module-c00000"></a> <div class="RichTextSidebarModule-title">Columnist </div> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody">Columnist</div> </div><p>Pritzker‚Äôs budget proposal does increase spending on ‚Äúmandated categoricals‚Äù for K-12 schools (things like special education, transportation and school lunches) by $51 million which, the governor‚Äôs office says, ‚Äúbenefit all districts.‚Äù</p><p>But the governor‚Äôs plan will raise the annual evidence-based funding plan ramp payment increase by just $5 million, to $305 million. Higher education spending will be limited to a 1 percent increase, similar to last year, and way behind inflation.</p><p>The day before the governor delivered his proposed budget to lawmakers, rumors circulated among legislators that K-12 education would receive an additional $200 million. Some people assumed that money would be used to boost the state‚Äôs evidence-based funding law.</p><p>The governor‚Äôs budget proposal did indeed project $200 million in revenues from imposing a new ‚Äúsocial media platform fee,‚Äù and the money was earmarked for education. But, as I noted above, evidence-based funding was given only an additional $5 million on top of its (mostly) usual $300 million annual increase.</p><p>According to a PowerPoint presentation from the governor‚Äôs budget office, that $200 million, if approved and if the fee survives a legal challenge, would be ‚Äúdedicated to supporting education.‚Äù</p><p>My associate Isabel Miller asked Pritzker during his post-address news conference where that $200 million would go.</p><p>‚ÄúWell, guess what? The Legislature has a lot to say about how the money would be spent, but I think the important thing is that our education system, our K-12 system across the state, needs that kind of support,‚Äù Pritzker said. Then he moved on before she could follow up.</p><p>But wait, this is Pritzker‚Äôs own budget proposal. And all the revenue from that new fee are included in his spending plan. The governor‚Äôs budget wouldn‚Äôt balance without it.</p><p>So, I followed up with the governor‚Äôs office to ask where, specifically, that money was going.</p><p> ‚ÄúThe proposal is to deposit it into the Common School Fund ‚Äî the same place the Lottery is deposited ‚Äî to support the cost of K-12 education. The Common School Fund is one of the General Funds, so the deposit is reflected in the General Funds budget proposal.‚Äù</p><p>OK, but according to the governor‚Äôs budget book, the Common School Fund is expected to grow by $103 million in the coming fiscal year ‚Äî roughly half of the $200 million it‚Äôs receiving. And the Lottery‚Äôs contribution to the fund is projected to grow by $17 million (to $832 million out of a $6.96 billion fund budget).</p><p>Ironically, this sort of thing used to happen with the Lottery all the time. The gambling cash didn‚Äôt really add new money to school funding, but it did help the state shift an equal amount away to the rest of the budget every year.</p><p>In this case, $200 million is being added to the school fund, but, in the process, $114 million appears to have been shifted out of the fund to the rest of the budget.</p><p>Pritzker held a news conference Friday to tout his new proposal to <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/education/2025/02/21/chicago-students-share-mixed-feelings-on-pritzker-proposal-to-restrict-classroom-use-of-cellphones" >ban cellphones</a> in classrooms.</p><p>Afterward, the Illinois Federation of Teachers had seen enough and issued a sharply critical statement.</p><p>‚ÄúWhat educators will tell you is that creating more unfunded mandates while failing to fund the ones already on the books ‚Äî special education, nutritional supports for hungry children and school transportation ‚Äî is out of order,‚Äù said the federation's Executive Vice President Cyndi Oberle-Dahm via news release.</p><p>‚ÄúThe state of Illinois owes its students $6 billion for pre-K to Ph.D., and that is where the governor should start.‚Äù</p><p><i>Rich Miller also publishes Capitol Fax, a daily political newsletter, and CapitolFax.com.</i></p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-5b0000" name="module-5b0000"></a> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody">Send letters to <a class="Link" href="mailto:letters@suntimes.com" target="_blank" >letters@suntimes.com</a>. More about <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/submitting-opinion-and-letters" >how to submit here</a>.</div> </div><p></p>
entries.author: Rich Miller

entries.title: Cubs' Seiya Suzuki blasts home run in first spring-training game, asks for sun to be moved
entries.summary: <p>MESA, Ariz. ‚Äî If any doubt remained ‚Äî after head-turning batting practice all spring ‚Äî that <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/cubs" target="_blank" >Cubs</a> outfielder <b>Seiya Suzuki </b>was ready to hit in the World Baseball Classic, he erased it with a blistered home run to left-center field in his first Cactus League at-bat Friday.</p><p>Afterward, he told Cubs right-hander <b>Jameson Taillon </b>he had gotten a little jammed on that pitch.</p><p>‚Äò‚ÄòHe‚Äôs strong enough to put balls out,‚Äô‚Äô Taillon said after his start in the Cubs‚Äô 8-1 loss to the White Sox in their spring-training opener Friday. ‚Äò‚ÄòHopefully there‚Äôs 40 more of those from now until the end of the year.‚Äô‚Äô</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center><div class="Enhancement-item"> <div class="ExternalContent-wrapper" > <div class="TweetUrl"> <blockquote class="twitter-tweet"><p lang="en" dir="ltr">First home run of <a href="https://twitter.com/hashtag/SpringTraining?src=hash&ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw">#SpringTraining</a> for Seiya Suzuki üí• <a href="https://t.co/e8lmsoO6K3">pic.twitter.com/e8lmsoO6K3</a></p>— MLB (@MLB) <a href="https://twitter.com/MLB/status/2024942363555033175?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw">February 20, 2026</a></blockquote> <script async src="https://platform.twitter.com/widgets.js" charset="utf-8"></script> </div> </div> </div></div><p>Suzuki was in a jovial mood after his four innings Friday, joking in his postgame interview about the blinding sun overhead and his connection with new <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/white-sox/2026/02/20/munetaka-murakami-fashionably-late-impresses-in-cactus-league-debut" target="_blank" >White Sox slugger <b>Munetaka Murakami</b></a>.</p><p>In preparation for playing center field in the WBC for Team Japan, Suzuki started there instead of in right. Cubs manager <b>Craig Counsell </b>said he also plans to play Suzuki in center Sunday before he departs Monday for Tokyo.</p><p></p><p>‚Äò‚ÄòYou get a good view of the field [from center],‚Äô‚Äô Suzuki said through an interpreter. ‚Äò‚ÄòBut can they do something about the sun? If they could move it just a little bit, that would be nice.‚Äô‚Äô</p><p></p><p>Ah, yes, that age-old Arizona issue.</p><p></p><p>In the top of the fourth, Murakami lifted a deep fly to straightaway center. Suzuki tracked it back to the warning track, sunglasses on and glove extended to shade his eyes.</p><p></p><p>The ball, however, still disappeared in the glare, and Suzuki ducked as it landed behind him at the base of the wall.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center><div class="Enhancement-item"> <div class="ExternalContent-wrapper" > <div class="TweetUrl"> <blockquote class="twitter-tweet"><p lang="en" dir="ltr">Seiya Suzuki loses a ball in the sun so his Japan World Baseball Classic teammate Munetaka Murakami gets a double <a href="https://t.co/1LQ6LHVzgb">pic.twitter.com/1LQ6LHVzgb</a></p>— Talkin' Baseball (@TalkinBaseball_) <a href="https://twitter.com/TalkinBaseball_/status/2024957358565175513?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw">February 20, 2026</a></blockquote> <script async src="https://platform.twitter.com/widgets.js" charset="utf-8"></script> </div> </div> </div></div><p>Suzuki played the ricochet as Murakami trotted into second base with a two-run double, his second hit with the Sox.</p><p>‚Äò‚ÄòI loved him,‚Äô‚Äô Suzuki said of his Team Japan teammate. ‚Äò‚ÄòBut after the [fly ball], I hate him, and I‚Äôm not going to support him.‚Äô‚Äô</p><p></p><p>After getting the laugh he was looking for, Suzuki grinned and clarified he was kidding.</p><p></p><p>‚Äò‚ÄòWe‚Äôre in Chicago, same city,‚Äô‚Äô Suzuki said. ‚Äò‚ÄòHe‚Äôs probably going to be there by himself. So if there‚Äôs anything that I can do to support him, I would be more than happy to.‚Äô‚Äô</p><p></p><h3>Bregman‚Äôs debut</h3><p></p><p>Third baseman <b>Alex Bregman </b>donned Cubbie blue pinstripes for his first spring-training game with the team. Bregman, who is set to represent the United States in the WBC, played three innings and went 0-for-2 at the plate.</p><p></p><p>‚Äò‚ÄòSuper-cool to have all that energy in the ballpark,‚Äô‚Äô Bregman said.</p><p></p><p>Sloan Park‚Äôs announced attendance was 14,419, an impressive spring-training turnout.</p><p></p><h3>Taillon gets the loss</h3><p></p><p>Taillon, pitching on a slightly early schedule as he prepares to join Team Canada for the WBC, allowed four runs in 1‚Öî innings. He threw 34 pitches.</p><p></p><p>‚Äò‚ÄòWe‚Äôve been doing a lot of drill work and stuff, so I‚Äôm curious to show up tomorrow and to see what translated, what didn‚Äôt and what we can work on in between starts,‚Äô‚Äô Taillon said. ‚Äò‚ÄòObviously, two homers on pitches down the middle. Besides that, everything felt fine.‚Äô‚Äô</p><p></p><p>Those home runs came on a first-pitch fastball to Sox outfielder <b>Austin Hays </b>and on an 0-2 fastball to second baseman <b>Sam Antonacci.</b></p><bsp-listcarousel class="PageListE" data-module data-column-count=3 data-hide-authors="true" data-hide-categories="true" data-hide-dates="true" data-hide-descriptions="true" entries.title: Funeral held for Chicago teen who battled cancer while fighting for father's release from ICE detention
entries.summary: <p>The blue Ford Mustang that Ofelia Giselle Torres Hidalgo‚Äôs father gifted her helped escort the 16-year-old‚Äôs ivory coffin to St. William Parish on Friday morning in the Northwest Side's Montclare neighborhood. </p><p>Dozens of mourners hugged as they left the private funeral Mass on the cold, cloudy morning as church bells rang.</p><p>The Rev. Ryszard Gron, who delivered the funeral homily, told reporters outside the church that their community was ‚Äúlucky to be accompanying the family of Ofelia.‚Äù</p><p>‚ÄúOur future life will [always be based] on what we do here,‚Äù Gron said. ‚ÄúShe will be happy now, and she is happy now in the hands of God.‚Äù</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item"> 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/e210d63/2147483647/strip/true/crop/1054x592+0+48/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F96%2F3f%2Fcacd7cf7483c8aca30c8d6d6279f%2Fscreenshot-2026-02-20-at-6-17-14-pm.png" class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Ruben Torres Maldonado is shown with his two children and wife, Sandibell Hidalgo.<br></p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Provided</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>Following widespread demands for his release, including <a class="Link" href="https://www.instagram.com/reels/DP-PGMHjWQ-/" target="_blank" ><u>a video made by Ofelia</u></a> on social media, <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/immigration/2025/10/30/chicago-father-of-teen-battling-rare-cancer-ordered-released-from-ice-custody" target="_blank" ><u>Maldonado was released on bond</u></a> from U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement detention in late-October.</p><p>‚ÄúOfelia left us with a lot of light, a lot of strength,‚Äù said Reyna Torres, consul general of Mexico in Chicago, who spoke to reporters. ‚ÄúWe at the consulate are inspired by her life and we will continue working for our community, inspired precisely by the fight Ofelia [dealt] with while she was here.‚Äù</p><p>A Chicago immigration judge this week conditionally allowed Maldonado to receive a ‚Äúcancellation of removal‚Äù due to the impact his deportation would have on his children, who are U.S. citizens.</p><p>The ruling would provide him with a pathway to lawful permanent residency and eventually U.S. citizenship, according to the press release.</p><p>‚ÄúOfelia was heroic and brave in the face of ICE‚Äôs detention and threatened deportation of her father,‚Äù Kalman Resnick, her attorney said in a statement released the day after she died. ‚ÄúWe mourn Ofelia‚Äôs passing, and we hope that she will serve as a model for us all for how to be courageous and to fight for what‚Äôs right to our last breaths.‚Äù</p><p>A <a class="Link" href="https://www.gofundme.com/f/stand-with-ofelia-support-her-family-now" target="_blank" ><u>GoFundMe</u></a> page was started for Ofelia in October and has collected more than $150,000 as of Friday morning.</p><p><i>Contributing: Elleiana Green and Violet Miller</i><br></p>
entries.author: Mohammad Samra

entries.title: New White Sox hitting coach looks to put team's offensive struggles in past
entries.summary: <p>MESA, Ariz. ‚Äî <b>Derek Shomon</b> sees an exciting <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/white-sox" >White Sox</a> offense that is balanced with power and contact this year.</p><p>That‚Äôd be a welcome improvement from a woeful offense last season that finished near the bottom of many major offensive categories.</p><p>‚ÄúWe have some guys that can slug this year, we have some guys that are willing to play the small game and take advantage of a third baseman being back,‚Äù Shomon said. ‚Äú...It‚Äôs not an all slug offense, it‚Äôs not a necessarily BABIP [batting average on balls in play] offense. You kind of got this well-rounded thing in place. That‚Äôs exciting, right? So, you have multiple solutions.‚Äù</p><p>The Sox displayed much offense in early-game action Friday in their 8-1 win over the Cubs in the Cactus League opener.</p><p>"It's exciting,‚Äù Sox manager <b>Will Venable</b> said, noting a strong day from several newcomers, including a <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/white-sox/2026/02/20/munetaka-murakami-fashionably-late-impresses-in-cactus-league-debut" >double from <b>Munetaka Murakami</b> </a>and home runs from <b>Austin Hays</b> and <b>Sam Antonacci</b>. ‚ÄúWe're excited to be able to add those guys to our offense and to come out the first day and put a couple nice swings on the ball was great and those guys are going to be in the middle of our lineup all year, so it's exciting to see."</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center><div class="Enhancement-item"> <div class="ExternalContent-wrapper" > <div class="TweetUrl"> <blockquote class="twitter-tweet"><p lang="en" dir="ltr">The first White Sox home run of Spring Training belongs to Austin Hays! <a href="https://t.co/38WVCfaSyy">pic.twitter.com/38WVCfaSyy</a></p>— Chicago White Sox (@whitesox) <a href="https://twitter.com/whitesox/status/2024940356111139124?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw">February 20, 2026</a></blockquote> <script async src="https://platform.twitter.com/widgets.js" charset="utf-8"></script> </div> </div> </div></div><p></p><p>The Sox are hoping the additions of Murakami, Hays, plus utilityman <b>Luisangel Acu√±a</b>, who did not play Friday, can help boost the offensive this year.</p><p>The team also is relying on four second-year players to build on relative success last season ‚Äî shortstop <b>Colson Montgomery</b>, second baseman <b>Chase Meidroth</b> and catchers <b>Kyle Teel</b> and <b>Edgar Quero</b>. They‚Äôll face challenges, however, adjusting to major league pitchers who now have a cache of their tape at the highest level.</p><p>Shomon highlighted their need to stay ahead of what pitchers have figured out about them.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-floatLeft> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-320000" name="image-320000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" Anderson/AP</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>‚ÄúThat very much is related to how you‚Äôre being attacked, and whether that‚Äôs pitch types, or certain zones, so on and so forth,‚Äù Shomon said. ‚ÄúJust the understanding that the game is going to give you the blueprint and your willingness to respond in a timely fashion is the ability to adjust and be able to perform.‚Äù</p><h3><b>Cannon‚Äôs first spring start</b></h3><p>Sox starting pitcher <b>Jonathan Cannon</b> finished his spring debut with 1‚Öî innings pitched, allowing one run ‚Äî a <b>Seiya Suzuki</b> home run ‚Äî and two hits, while walking one batter and striking out three.</p><p>Suzuki‚Äôs homer came on a sinker that Cannon left over the middle of the plate.</p><p>‚ÄúThat‚Äôs kind of been a point of emphasis this spring, working on that sinker and kind of using [that and the four-seam fastball],‚Äù Cannon said. ‚ÄúAnd then just kind of dialing back in the offspeed command, I thought that could be better. That was just kind of the point of improvement going forward, could definitely be more in the zone a little bit more. But overall, I thought it was good, a lot to build off of, long spring ahead.‚Äù</p><h3><b>Pereira late scratch from lineup</b></h3><p>Outfielder <b>Everson Pereira</b> was scratched from Friday‚Äôs lineup for precautionary reasons due to general soreness, Venable said. He‚Äôs listed as day to day, then ‚Äúwe‚Äôll see where he‚Äôs at,‚Äù Venable said.</p><p>The 24-year-old former top 100 prospect has impressed Venable early in spring training with his power potential, but his ability to make contact has fallen behind.</p><p>Pereira said earlier this week that it‚Äôs ‚Äúprobably impossible‚Äù for him to sacrifice some power in exchange to becoming a better contact hitter.</p><p>‚ÄúBut I think if you are able to make contact with the ball and you are strong enough, the ball is going to carry itself,‚Äù Pereira said.</p><h3><b>Sox 8, Cubs 1</b></h3><p>‚Ä¢ Hays homered on the first pitch he saw, launching a down-the-middle fastball to the left-center lawn. Antonacci, a Springfield product and a top prospect in the Sox' system, also homered in his first at-bat. He topped it off with an enthusiastic bat flip.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center><div class="Enhancement-item"> <div class="ExternalContent-wrapper" > <div class="TweetUrl"> <blockquote class="twitter-tweet"><p lang="hi" dir="ltr">Sam Antonacci. SHEESH! üò§ <a href="https://t.co/zcqRUmYhz5">pic.twitter.com/zcqRUmYhz5</a></p>— Chicago White Sox (@whitesox) <a href="https://twitter.com/whitesox/status/2024944285108633794?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw">February 20, 2026</a></blockquote> <script async src="https://platform.twitter.com/widgets.js" charset="utf-8"></script> </div> </div> </div></div><p>‚Ä¢ Catcher Korey Lee, fighting for a roster spot, went 3-for-4 with a single, walk and a stolen base.</p><p>‚Ä¢ Braden Montgomery, the No. 36 prospect, per <a class="Link" href="http://mlb.com" target="_blank" ><u>MLB.com</u></a>, slapped an RBI triple in his first at-bat. Darren Baker, the son of former Cubs manager Dusty Baker, scored on the hit.</p><p>‚Ä¢ On deck: Sox vs. A‚Äôs, 2:05 p.m. Saturday, Glendale, Arizona, ESPN 1000-AM, Chris Murphy vs. entries.title: Arlington Heights man charged in Thursday‚Äôs 7¬Ω-hour standoff
entries.summary: <p>Police announced charges Friday for a 50-year-old Arlington Heights man who authorities say illegally entered an Arlington Heights home Thursday and engaged police in a 7¬Ω-hour standoff that prompted a soft lockdown at nearby schools and the Arlington Heights Memorial Library.</p><p>Alex R. Pacino will appear for a detention hearing Saturday on charges of home invasion and aggravated discharge of a firearm, class X felonies that carry non-probationable sentences ranging from six to 30 years.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-bd0000" name="image-bd0000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/8113155/2147483647/strip/true/crop/848x476+0+123/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F44%2Ff9%2Fd92a5894444da8a34b7ad68a10d0%2Fscreenshot-2026-02-20-at-6-26-24-pm.png 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/dd7f265/2147483647/strip/true/crop/848x476+0+123/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F44%2Ff9%2Fd92a5894444da8a34b7ad68a10d0%2Fscreenshot-2026-02-20-at-6-26-24-pm.png 2x" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <source width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/3816db2/2147483647/strip/true/crop/848x476+0+123/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F44%2Ff9%2Fd92a5894444da8a34b7ad68a10d0%2Fscreenshot-2026-02-20-at-6-26-24-pm.png" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="Alex R. Pacino" srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/3816db2/2147483647/strip/true/crop/848x476+0+123/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F44%2Ff9%2Fd92a5894444da8a34b7ad68a10d0%2Fscreenshot-2026-02-20-at-6-26-24-pm.png 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/a5dc5ea/2147483647/strip/true/crop/848x476+0+123/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F44%2Ff9%2Fd92a5894444da8a34b7ad68a10d0%2Fscreenshot-2026-02-20-at-6-26-24-pm.png 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/3816db2/2147483647/strip/true/crop/848x476+0+123/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F44%2Ff9%2Fd92a5894444da8a34b7ad68a10d0%2Fscreenshot-2026-02-20-at-6-26-24-pm.png" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Alex R. Pacino</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Provided</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>About 7:33 a.m. Thursday, Arlington Heights police received a report of a burglary in progress. Homeowners told authorities a man wearing dark clothing and a hoodie had entered the residence through an open overhead garage door. The homeowners responded by locking themselves in a second-floor bedroom and calling 911.</p><p>Police arrived to the sound of gunfire. While some officers escorted the residents to safety, others observed a man, later identified as Pacino, attempting to flee through a window.</p><p>For more on this story, please visit <a class="Link" href="https://www.dailyherald.com/20260220/news/arlington-heights-man-charged-in-thursdays-7%c2%bd-hour-standoff/" target="_blank" >DailyHerald.com</a>. <br></p>
entries.author: Daily Herald

entries.title: 2 Chicago men arrested in undercover federal firearms probe
entries.summary: <p>Two men were arrested Wednesday in connection with an undercover federal firearms investigation in the Chicago area, according to federal prosecutors in Chicago. </p><p>Matthew Barraza, 21, was arrested and charged with unlicensed dealing of a firearm, possession of a machine gun and distribution of a controlled substance. Edwin Moreno, 27, was arrested on suspicion of possessing machine gun. </p><p>Barraza, a resident of Chicago, illegally sold a loaded handgun to an undercover law enforcement officer for $2,000 and 127 grams of cocaine for $3,600 at a Bolingbrook gas station on Feb. 5, according to a criminal complaint filed in U.S. District Court in Chicago. </p><p>The handgun was equipped with a machine gun conversion device and an extended magazine containing 19 rounds of ammunition, the complaint said. </p><p>Moreno, also a resident of Chicago, was in possession of a firearm equipped with a machine gun conversion device Jan. 15 when undercover law enforcement officers disguised as tow operators conducted a vehicle repossession in Joliet, the complaint said. </p><p>Barraza and Moreno will appear before U.S. Magistrate Judge Laura K. McNally in federal court Wednesday. </p>
entries.author: Elleiana Green
